qas.question: In 1944 who called on all Yuboslavs to come together under Tito's leadership?
With whom did Tito sign an agreement on September 28 1944?
Who were allowed "temporary entry" into Yugoslav territory?
Who assisted in operations in ortheastern areas of Yugoslavia?
Who executed a massive offensive and succeeded in breaking through German lines?

context: On 12 September 1944, <a0_0>King Peter II<a0_0/> called on all Yugoslavs to come together under Tito's leadership and stated that those who did not were "traitors", by which time Tito was recognized by all Allied authorities (including the government-in-exile) as the Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, in addition to commander-in-chief of the Yugoslav forces. On 28 September 1944, the Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union (TASS) reported that Tito signed an agreement with the <a1_0>Soviet Union<a1_0/> allowing "temporary entry" of <a2_0>Soviet troops<a2_0/> into Yugoslav territory which allowed the <a3_0>Red Army<a3_0/> to assist in operations in the northeastern areas of Yugoslavia. With their strategic right flank secured by the Allied advance, <a4_0>the Partisans<a4_0/> prepared and executed a massive general offensive which succeeded in breaking through German lines and forcing a retreat beyond Yugoslav borders. After the Partisan victory and the end of hostilities in Europe, all external forces were ordered off Yugoslav territory.
